awd_titl_txt: Molecular-neural basis for motor patterning of vocal-acoustic signals
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding how the brain controls behavior is a major goal in neuroscience. All behavioral actions, including those as different as walking, singing, even tiny eye movements that allow one to focus on a page of text, ultimately depend on the activation of muscles by motor neurons in the brain. The remarkable range of actions that animals are capable of begs the question: how different are the motor neurons underlying different behaviors? One strategy for answering this is to compare neurons driving different behaviors. Modern bony fishes are champions in the ability to generate vocalizations that exhibit rapid, precisely timed sound pulses. The studies proposed here use fish as model systems to compare vocal motor neuron populations to those that pattern non-vocal motor behaviors: locomotion that depends on fin movement, and electric signaling generated by modified muscle cells that are used by fish for communication and active sensing of the aquatic environment. The project will determine the extent to which molecular, genetic and physiological properties are shared in motor neurons driving these behaviors that differ in their temporal patterning, for example, fast (vocal and electric) vs. slow (fin movement). The Principal Investigator will continue to recruit a talented population of men and women students from diverse backgrounds, including underrepresented minorities, and train them in behavioral, neural, and molecular levels of analysis. 

More specifically, molecular, genetic and neurophysiological methods in several model systems among fishes will be used to address the following questions: 1) Can similarities in the neurophysiological patterning of vocal motor behavior between distantly related species be explained by a similar set of gene products that underlies a shared set of vocal motor neuron characters (Aim 1)?  2) Do vocal motor neurons employ a "molecular toolkit" distinct from that of non-vocal motor neurons exhibiting lower degrees of synchrony and temporal precision, in this case the pectoral motor system for locomotion (Aim 2)?  3) Do vocal motor neurons employ a shared "molecular toolkit" with that of non-vocal motor neurons exhibiting comparable degrees of synchronicity, temporal precision and rapid firing, in this case the electromotor system that is used for active sensing of objects in the aquatic environment (Aim 3)? By complementing large-scale gene expression studies with neuro-pharmacological validation, these aims will identify how patterns of gene expression determine neurobiological and behavioral phenotypes, in this case those determining divergent motor functions.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit.  All behavioral actions, from walking and singing to even the tiny eye movements allowing us to focus on these words, ultimately depend on the activation of muscles by motor neurons. Precise neuronal firing is of special importance in motor systems where there are demands on the correct sequencing and timing of muscle activity patterns that are essential to the successful performance of behavior. This includes acoustic signalling (vocalization) that is widespread among several major vertebrate groups. A practical way to study such behaviors is to investigate them in species such as fish, largely because their behaviors and underlying anatomical and physiological processes are relatively simple. This project addressed basic neural mechanisms underlying acoustic behaviors shared by all major groups of sonic vertebrates. There have been several significant outcomes.

(1) Highly precise vocal timing: A system that exhibits rapid, precisely timed sound pulses, making it ideal to study precise neuronal firing, is the hindbrain pattern generator of toadfishes, a group of marine teleost fish that depend on acoustic signals for mate attraction and nest defence. Hundreds of hindbrain motor neurons fire in synchrony within 1.5 milliseconds at frequencies up to 250 Hz for time periods ranging from hundreds of milliseconds to minutes. Using intracellular recordings from neurons together with pharmacological manipulations, these studies showed evidence for a mechanism (feed-forward glycinergic inhibition dependent on gap junction/electrotonic coupling) that leads to increased temporal precision in the activity of a motor neuron population underlying vocalization that likely also contributes to the sequencing of sounds used in vocalization. The extent of neuronal precision across an entire population generated in this system by far exceeds the magnitude of synchronization known from other pattern generating circuits. Neuronal synchrony leading to rapid and precise activation of muscles in other vocal vertebrates, including birds and mammals, might all benefit from a similar mechanism. More broadly, this system could provide more insights into the fine temporal control of the activity of neuron populations in other motor systems.

(2) Circadian regulation of vocalization: A suite of genes were identified in this vocal network that together underscore the role of differential gene expression in shifts between behavioral states, in particular the circadian control of sound production.

(3) New model for acoustic signaling behavior: The freshwater minnow, Danionella dracula, is a miniature and transparent vertebrate that offers several advantages for using whole-brain neuroimaging and neurogenetics and to study neuromodulation of adult social behavior, in this case sound production in an aggressive context. Adults only reach about 17 mm in length, making them highly amenable to neuroimaging of the entire adult central nervous system. Danionella are also closely related to zebrafish, a major neurogenetic model, which is making Danionella especially amenable to genetic manipulation. Unlike zebrafish, this species produces concurrent, highly stereotyped acoustic and postural displays in an aggressive context, thus providing a novel system to study the role of acoustic communication in aggression. 

Broader Impact. The Principal Investigator continued to recruit and train a diverse population of 15 undergraduates and two graduate students in behavioral, neural, and molecular methods of scientific investigation, inclusive of critical thinking and problem-solving skills that will be valuable in the pursuit of any profession they choose to follow. The Principal Investigator and/or lab undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral associates:

(1) presented their scientific findings in high visibility, peer-reviewed journals and at local, national, and international conferences

(2) participated in local outreach activities, for example, the Cornell University outreach program for graduate students (GRASHOPR) and Kids Science Day, and mentored undergraduates in resume preparation for the Knight Writing Program,

(3) provided photographs for children?s books, textbooks and websites, and interviews reporting the lab?s studies, for example, for Swedish Public Service Television; Auditory Language Group, University of Geneva; Popular Science magazine; BYU Radio; and The Atlantic.

(4) maintained their intellectual engagement and team-driven participation in all projects during the COVID pandemic.

The Principal Investigator also served as the College of Arts and Sciences Diversity Lead at Cornell and was a member of the Arts and Sciences Diversity and Equity Committee that focused on faculty yearly reporting of research, teaching, student advising, and outreach activities, and the recruitment of new faculty.
